name: A. Indirect Sort
statement:
You are given a permutation a_1, a_2,
ldots, a_n of size n, where each integer from 1 to n appears .You can do
the following operation any number of times (possibly, zero): Choose any
three indices i, j, k (1
le i < j < k
le n). If a_i > a_k, replace a_i with a_i + a_j. Otherwise, swap a_j and
a_k. Determine whether you can make the array a sorted in non-descending
order.
editorial:
SolutionWe claim that we can sort the array if and only if .NecessityWe
can notice that index cannot be affected by any swap operation.Letâs see
what happens to the value . According to the definition of the
operation, it can either increase or be swapped. In order to be
increased, there must exist some such that , but since is the minimum
possible value, it will never be true as other values in array can only
increse as well. Since index can not be affected by a swap operation and
, we conclude that if , the answer is No.SufficiencyLetâs focus on the
second operation. Since we have , we can always choose and the operation
then turns into picking some pair and swapping with . Itâs trivial to
see we can always sort with such an operation.
